subject: Re: New file uploaded to Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: ... Quikscript Project/Intro and Notes.pdf ... Thanks.  Credit to you to also, since it is heavily based on your proposal :) ... put ... given ... would ...
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> peter_r_guinness scripsit:
>
> > File : /International Quikscript/Malt's International
Quikscript Project/Intro and Notes.pdf
> > Uploaded by : peter_r_guinness <malt99@...>
>
> I think this is an excellent proposal. A few points:
>

Thanks. Credit to you to also, since it is heavily based on your
proposal :)

> In the four cases NEAR, CURE, FIRE, SHOWER you've decided whether to
put
> in an Utter or not based on ease of writing, which is reasonable
given
> Quikscript's purposes. It's more or less an arbitrary choice: I
would
> have gone without an Utter in NEAR, CURE and with one in FIRE,
SHOWER.
>

Yes, I agree that the options here are rather arbitrary. As you have
noted, I've based my choice mainly on the ease of writing.
The use of the ligatures for these cases in the spreadsheets allows
them to be substituted gobally throughout easily with whatever people
decide is best.

> It's worth adding some examples to rule 31 that don't involve "ew",
> such as tune, dune, lute.
>

Good idea, will add some examples soon.
I have also fixed up some other minor things since uploading it.
I also expect that there will be need for more consonant rules in the
future and will add them when necessary.

> I haven't been able to look at the spreadsheet yet. Is it posted?
>

At the moment it is not one large spreadsheet. I have broken it down
into smaller spreadsheets based on Part-Of-Speech. So far I have
completed the most common- pronouns, determiners, determiner_pronouns.
They are available at :
Files/International_Quikscript/Malt's_International_Quikscript_Project
.
I'm currently working on a list of common prepositions. I expect it
to take a few months before I have a solid list of nouns/verbs/adverb
etc., since I haven't all that much spare time for this and it is
quite a slow process requiring each word to be looked up twice- once
in Longman's and then the MacQuarie (admittedly I'm probably being too
pedantic about it).

There is something that I would be glad to have your opinion on. I'm
not sure which is the best letter to use for the General American
spelling of the sound /o/. Such as in FORCE set word alternatives
like _more_ -> /mor/ -> May+?+Roe. (Under the proposal the IntQS
spelling is May+Awe+Roe but I don't know what the GA spelling should
be). I don't have this sound as a pure vowel in my Australian accent
so am not very familiar with it but from what understand it is the
first phone of the way I pronouce the diphthong Owe /oU/. Would Owe be
the best choice of QS letter?

Thanks
malt.
